title: Contract Software Engineer
description: Worked in a contract role in DMS' R&D department during development of a portable version of their Partial-discharge (PD) condition monitoring server (CMS). DMS' PDM product monitors high voltage Gas Insulated Switchgear (GIS) in electrical installations for PD events, providing engineers with AI-based analysis used to pinpoint issues before catastrophic failure occurs. Integrated with existing plant SCADA systems, data is collected from potentially hundreds of sensors across an installation. Investigated and profiled the SQL Server-based database back-end of the existing CMS, with a view to replacing it with a suitable embedded alternative capable of running on a Windows Embedded Compact 7 (WEC7) platform with an Atom CPU. Designed a SQLite based solution for the embedded platform. Created a new DB-agnostic storage layer to allow re-use of much of the existing CMS database code while allowing the bottom layer to be compiled for both the server and embedded targets. Wrote a SQLite implementation for the embedded target, and ported the existing database subsystem to WEC7 using it. Help develop the Silverlight for Windows Embedded (SWE) based User Interface for the portable product, using an MVVM/MVC methodology and XAML. Developed a custom Electronic Change Request (ECR) system for intenal DMS use using a C# Winforms UI backed by a SQL Server database. Technologies: C/C++/C# (VS), OLE DB, ATL, Winforms, SQL Server, SQLite, Windows 7, Windows Embedded Compact, Silverlight for Windows Embedded, XAML, MVVM/MVC, Ant, CruiseControl
address: Qualitrol Company LLC 1385 Fairport Road Fairport, New York 14450 United States
name: Jonathan Hay

groups.name: University of Strathclyde - Computer and Electronic Systems Engineering Alumni

title: Embedded Software Engineer (Contract)
description: Worked in a contract role in Optos' R&D department during development of the Daytona ultra-widefield retinal imaging system. Daytona performs high speed, wide-field laser scans of the retina for clinical use, using proprietary optics. Compiled/remastered a custom Ubuntu Linux distribution, 'Nurburg', for use with the Daytona hardware. Responsible for integrating the 'Nurburg' linux-based operating system and C++ application software with the main System Control Module (SCM) FPGA/PLD chip, which controlled much of the Daytona proprietary hardware. This involved writing driver software for communicating with the chip over I2C and motherboard GPIO resources, as well as extensive work on the C++ hardware control subsystem. Added automatic Avalanche Photodiode (APD) calibration code to Daytona for the laser detectors. Debugged/overhauled the GNU make-based build system for Daytona/Nurburg, allowing for automated production of Debian packages containing the latest builds. Evangelised for the use of the Debian packaging system to simplify software deployment, and wrote build scripts to semi-automate production of redistributable Nurburg images from releases, greatly increasing development efficiency. Technologies: C/C++ (Visual Studio/gcc), Python, GNU make, Qt, Lattice MachX02 FPGA, svn, user and kernel mode GNU/linux
address: Queensferry House - Carnegie Campus Enterprise Way Dunfermline, Scotland KY11 8GR United Kingdom
name: Jonathan Hay

groups.name: University of Strathclyde - Computer and Electronic Systems Engineering Alumni

title: Software Engineer
description: Worked as part of a large international team, porting functionality from Cisco IOS (bare metal, run-to-completion O/S) to Cisco's next-gen embedded linux-based router operating system, and writing new features. This involved development and porting work on PowerPC, MIPS, and x86-based platforms. Focused on the packet classification, WCCP, and QoS features of the forwarding and feature manager (FFM), but in a broad capacity; including everything from IPC to forwarding drivers to database manipulation. Involved in 3 major projects throughout the entire development life-cycle. Took a leading role in the design of several components of the forwarding manager feature code, which is part of a scalable, high-performance, distributed High-Availability (HA) architecture. Frequently debugged complex issues in multi-threaded, distributed systems as part of a multi-disciplinary team. This task was complicated by the use of prototype (in other words, buggy) hardware. Redesigned the state distribution model of FFMs packet classification engine to improve scalability, resulting in an order-of-magnitude reduction in required backplane traffic. Regularly integrated code with dozens of feature teams distributed across 3 time zones. Frequently involved in branch syncs/collapses and ensuring commit criteria were met. Worked in a highly challenging engineering environment, with an enormous codebase (10's of MLOCs), spread across dozens of divergent branches in multiple SCM systems. Promoted to Grade 8 Engineer in February 2011. Mentored other engineers in the integration of their feature components with the forwarding manager. Technologies: C/C++ (gcc compiler), gdb, QEMU emulator, GNU make, Python, custom IDLs, embedded linux, Clearcase SCMS, shell scripting, UML
address: 170 West Tasman Dr.  San Jose, CA 95134 United States
name: Jonathan Hay

groups.name: University of Strathclyde - Computer and Electronic Systems Engineering Alumni

title: Kernel-mode Software Engineer
description: Worked on the interceptor component of Neverfail's Heartbeat server failover/replication product: a kernel-mode driver which facilitates the capture of interesting low-level file-system activity for replication purposes. As an extension of the operating system, the interceptor driver participates in complex interactions between the OS, file system, memory manager, and CPU in a multi-threaded environment. Integrated the native driver code with the Java-based components of the Heartbeat application using memory shared between the OS and the JVM. He was particularly honored to be charged with the design and oversight of the organizations annual report for 2005 and it remains a centerpiece in his current portfolio. Sterling Savings Bank announced its acquisition of Sonoma National Bank in October, 2006, less than a year into his tenure there. He also provided network design and administration, support for 24 user network, 6 printers and a new automated VoIP phone/VM system. Matt also contributed to the growth of the owners' artisan winery housed on the same property. His responsibility included webmaster for adoberoadwines.com, the design of bottle labels, collateral marketing pieces and packaging for the winery. Some days, Matt put in 14 to 16 hours serving these two growing companies and left the Racers Group to pursue a career that was more in keeping with the needs of his growing family. He misses racing and the synergy he felt with the team while preparing Porsche race cars for their presentation on the national and world stage. company: Bemco & Almabani Engineering and Contracting Co Qatar (Unicorp)
description: 1. Managing through subordinate supervisors and directing staff activities to provide timely services to other work units throughout the Department and ensure efficient daily operation of the work unit and accountability and adherence to applicable laws, policies and procedures. 2. Supervising the work unit and personnel, which includes: interviewing prospective employees; providing and/or recommending training; coordinating, scheduling and assigning work product; establishing performance measures, goals, objectives and priorities; evaluating work performance; providing feedback, direction and guidance; keeping personnel abreast of new or revised information; answering questions; and recommending and/or implementing personnel actions. Prioritizing and assigning tasks and projects to staff; tracking and reviewing work progress. 3. Conducting briefings to management or other executives to report information and answer questions. 4. Providing communication systems by identifying needs; evaluating options; maintaining equipment; approving invoices. 5. Maintaining continuity among corporate, division, and local work teams by documenting and communicating actions, irregularities, and continuing needs. 6. Developing policies and procedures to outline employee responsibilities and correct actions to be taken. 7. Tracking time-sensitive events to meet deadlines. 8. Reviewing and recommending approval, modification or rejection of proposals to ensure conformance with federal and state guidelines. 9. Reviewing and overseeing contracts, agreements, and/or leases to ensure service is in compliance with the contract and to verify accuracy of figures. 10. Monitoring and approving the expenditure of funds, both appropriated and non-appropriated, to ensure proper financial procedures have been followed 11. In full charge of the following departments and their procedures: HR/Admin, Procurement and Stores, Logistics and transportation and Camp.

title: Group Track Hire Manager
description: Overall responsibility for planning the calendars to maximise the commercial track hire revenues at MSV’s five venues -Brands Hatch, Oulton Park, Snetterton, Cadwell Park & Bedford Autodrome, increasing annual revenues by 81% between ‘05 and ‘11. Account management of all commercial track hire clients – automotive manufacturers & agents, car & bike track day operators, clubs, teams, film companies, media & other organisations who hired the circuits for non-racing activities. Client spend was anything from £250 to £1.6m. From ‘05 to ‘13, I delivered an increase in annual track day operator spend of 64%. Initiated, developed and managed Club MSV (now MSVT), the in-house track day business with 6 full time & 50 part time staff. Overseeing strategy, product development, marketing, advertising, media partnerships, community interaction, social media & event delivery. Started from scratch in ‘05, now turning over £2m pa with a database of 6500 customers. Initiated & developed 2 highly successful car racing series (Trackday Trophy & Team Trophy) specifically for novices, converting over 350 trackday drivers into racers & consistently providing the biggest grids in UK club motorsport in 2012 & 2013. Developed long term commercial relationships with automotive manufacturers & their agencies, improving the event management service propositions with hands-on event planning and delivery. Managed the account of MSV’s automotive commercial partner, working closely with them on event strategy, format, budgeting & delivery. Developed car & bike testing formats, increasing revenue by 70% from ‘05 to ‘13. Produced elements of the MSV website with active influence over promotional copy, functionality & booking systems. Managed relationships with automotive media for commercial partnerships & exclusive events. Produced the commercial terms of track hire & operational guidelines. Director of the Association of Racing Driver Schools on behalf of MSV.
address: Fawkham  Longfield, Kent DA3 8NG United Kingdom
name: Ian Berry

groups.name: Event Planning & Event Management - the 1st Group for Event Professionals

title: Marketing Director
description: Manufacturer of GameRacer domestic race simulators for use with gaming consoles. I co-designed the product with of one of the UK’s top kart chassis designers & we formed a partnership. My role was then to implement the sales & marketing of the product. Within 18 months GameRacer had become the UK’s market leading domestic race simulator, together with significant sales to Norway, Sweden, France, Greece & the USA. In 2004, with sales approaching 2000 units a year, I sold my half share in the company to my business partner.

I also occasionally wrote for other kart industry publications and conducted a driver search for Track & Race Car magazine, producing editorial about the scheme and subsequent shoot out competition.

title: Series Co-ordinator
description: On behalf of Playscape Pro-Racing I managed & developed every aspect of this ground breaking ‘arrive and drive’ 2-stroke karting series from its inception. My responsibilities included creating the event calendar, booking circuits, financial planning, marketing, advertising, production of the newsletters, data capture, event management, race directing, clerking & instructing at the events. By 1999, Club 100 had become the largest kart racing series in the UK and is still hugely successful.

description: I worked with karts, quad bikes, Pilots, Apaches & Caterhams for various clients including Brands Hatch, Business Pursuits, Buckmore Park, Daytona Raceway, Playscape Pro Racing, Kart City, Spitfire Karting, Trak 1 & Palmersport. title: Vice President - Venture Debt
description: Three Point Capital Venture Debt provides non-dilutive financing options to start-ups and growing companies in the form of corporate loans. As part of this vehicle, Three Point is sector agnostic, with a preference for companies with at least $1 MM in annualized revenue, and business models that are characterized by revenue that is either driven by a subscription model (SaaS, content, commerce, box of the month, etc) or long-term, sticky revenue tied to enterprise, government or government entity contracts. In addition to these business models, Three Point is opportunistic around special situations, including acquisitions, and typically targets investments ranging from $500k to $5 MM.

title: System Analysis & Design Lead - FRES Utility Vehicle (UV)
description: “The overall FRES programme will deliver a fleet of vehicles, comprising five families of vehicle: Utility; Reconnaissance; Fires; Manoeuvre Support; and a family of simpler variants known as the Basic Capability Utility). The FRES fleet will comprise over 3000 vehicles in total, the largest of which will be the Utility family at approximately 2000. The FRES fleet of vehicles will be fitted with subsystems (some common across the fleet) and interface to other platforms and systems across the battlespace. The subsystems will be integrated seamlessly across the FRES fleet; with the remainder of the AFV (non FRES) fleet; with all Defence Lines of Development (DLOD); and with the wider battlespace to ensure that a fully coherent and well integrated FRES capability is delivered to the user.” FRES will be the largest UK defence programme in history, with the initial procurement estimated at approximately £16bn and a whole life cost of around £40bn. In this role, I am responsible for leading the FRES Systems Analysis & Design Team. The main purpose of this team is to support the UV & SV bidding process by improving General Dynamics understanding of the customer requirements and any associated technical risks. As part of this team, my main responsibilities were to provide technical direction and oversight of: • Analysis of the customer supplied SRDs relating to the FRES UV and SV Programmes. • Development of a FRES System Architecture that could be utilised to support commonality across the fleet and different families • Selection of the most appropriate FRES system architecture and system / subsystem approach • Documentation of the FRES System Architecture and Design using SysML • Full requirements traceability to the architecture/design and other supporting analysis • Production of Engineering artefacts (including an ADD, SSRDs & SSDD) • Documentation of the system engineering process, modelling guidelines & working practises

title: Senior Software Engineer - GP3
description: GP3 was a command and control information system (C2IS) deployed at headquarters ARRC that has recently been replaced by ARRC2IS. It provided a common information infrastructure and set of situational awareness and staff planning tools, which combined to allow commanders and staff officers to carry out G2 (Intelligence) and G3 (Operations/Plans) functions in an efficient and co-operative manner. This three-tier system utilised the Microsoft DCOM/COM Model to provide co-operative working within a single headquarters. It was hosted on NT client/server infrastructures and also utilised wide-area-networks for inter-headquarter information sharing. Inter-Headquarter information sharing was achieved via its unique replication/distribution mechanism. During my assignment on GP3 I fulfilled various roles: • GIS System Architect/Developer - Map and Overlay Manager • APP6-A/MIL-STD-2525 Symbology Team Leader • CM Administrator • Integration & Test Engineering • Build & Installation Support • Army Trials Support & System Administrator

title: Defence Software Consultant - STAMGEN Interactive Display (SID)
description: STAMGEN (Surveillance and Target Acquisition Message GENerator) was a simulation used to investigate the performance of different sensor systems for the British Army. The simulation grew to accurately represent many aspects of a ground battle, placing the sensor systems in an increasingly realistic environment from where their relative performance could be assessed. I developed a terrain painter utility for SID (STAMGEN interactive Display) in response to a new client requirement. The terrain painter utility provided a means of assigning feature classifications such as tree cover to sections of a battlefield terrain. The development was carried out on Sun Workstations under Solaris, and was written in C++ with the aid of the ILOG Views GUI library. I had sole responsibility for design, development, testing and documentation.

title: Network Engineer (Voice Switching, SS7 Services, and Central Office Eng)
description: Missouri Network Alliance (now a part of Bluebird Network) was a Network founded in 1999 by 15 Independent Rural Telephone Companies that brought Broadband Services and Connectivity to many communities and businesses in the State of Missouri. My contributions: • Assistance in Network Design and Implementation of the Missouri Network Alliance Tandem. Creating for a high-speed, low latency, fault tolerant Platform for Class-4 Voice Switching Platform for 15 ILEC's and 23 End Offices. • Provisioned Circuits in Sonet Network (DS-0, DS-1, DS-3 OC-3, OSC-3c, OC-12 facilitating the transmission of Voice and Circuit Switched Data to the Missouri Network Alliance Tandem. • Facilitated in Circuit Design, Circuit Orders, Firm Order Commitments, and Supplementation for Inter Exchange Carriers Inter-connectivity to the Missouri Network Alliance Tandem. • Created Test and Validation Procedures for all Trunk Testing, Call Termination, Call Testing, and Translation Verification for all End Offices re-homing Feature Group D Services to the Missouri Network Alliance Tandem. • Provisioned and helped maintain the DS-0 Circuits for MNA's SS7 Aggregate STP Platform, including Route Costing, Implementation of A-Links, and Route Sets. Included Testing and Verification. • Responsible for detailing procedures in SS7 Protocol Analyzer for Queries as well as Signaling. Mentored other technical employees in SS7 Troubleshooting Methods and how to isolate anomalies and Least Cost Routing instances. • Developed Formal Troubleshooting Procedures for engagement of Technical Resources and distributed to End Offices, greatly assisting, explaining and resolving Call Completion, CABS Billing, and Call Quality Issues. • Performed Collocation and Collocation Augment Applications with RBOC's/ILEC's in the State of Missouri. • Procured parts and electronics for installation and implementation as Central Office Engineer. Included Rack and Cabling Layouts, Scope of Work Summaries, and Job Start Agreements.

title: Network Engineer II. (Network Quality Engineering/Tools & Service Availability)
description: Focused on a new objective with a new direction within Sprint-Nextel. Network Quality Assurance/Engineering was a task force of Subject Matter Experts focused on improving the Sprint-Nextel Network Reliability and Availability. As a team member of NQA/NQE my responsibilities were: • Dedicated work as a liaison between Field Operations, Switch Operations, and Centralized Network Operations (which included NOC's and NTAC) • Responsible for Project Coordination of Alarm Library Library Testing of all existing and new Vendor Platforms into Sprint-Nextel's Production Network. • Responsible for writing command syntax and rules for Automated Processing for Testing and Certification of circuits as well as full Cell Site/Card/Sector resets. • Created training curriculum for Nortel Cellular Network in partnership with Sprint University of Excellence. • Created troubleshooting Job Aides for every Actionable Alarm in the Nortel MTX/iDEN Switch/P-MSC (Packet Mobile Switching Center) with Summary, Definition, Root Cause, and Resolution Action for Field Operations/Network Operations Center in IBM Netcool System. • Responsible for working with multiple work groups (Network Operations Centers and Field Operations) which supported IBM-Netcool/HP-Openview/TTI-Netrac II/Kiwi/Homegrown Trap Collectors. • Lead Project team to standardize Trap Collection format from all Vendors, including detailed instructions on how to host an Alarm Library Review, How to break down the Alarm Messaging/Code, and how to Specify/Request Enhancements through Change Control Processes for different Device API's. • Mentored Several Engineers in Sprint Technical Triage (Developmental TAC). Assisted in Troubleshooting calls with Market/NTAC/Vendors. • Discovered multiple missing traps and alarms that were Critical in Nature on P-MSC Platform. Worked with Sprint STIC (Sprint Testing and Integration Center) Lab to validate Code and Performance of latest Software Revisions on this platform.

title: Certified Senior Advisor® (CSA)
company: Caring Transitions of Montgomery County Maryland
description: If your about to face a senior transition in yours or a spouses life necessitating a move to an independent, assisted living or nursing care community and are overwhelmed by the task we can help. If you're a baby boomer facing the inevitable decisions regarding how best to help your parents and ensure their well being, Caring Transitions can help you with all those decisions. Or if your a baby boomer family about to retire, sell your present home and relocate locally or out-of-state, we can take care of your transition. We can do all of this, saving you the drudgery and risks associated with contacting and meeting with numerous contractors when we can provide all these same services with just one simple phone call. One Company! One Call And We Do It All. Caring Transitions of Montgomery County.

title: Art Teacher
description: After leaving the ad business I wanted a totally new challenge that had nothing to do with the business community. I decided to offer my talents where they might do some good. Working as an art teacher with inner city elementary school children was incredibly rewarding experience and I'm glad I did it. But as I taught I started to miss the juice of entrepreneurship, realizing I needed to once again, open my own business. My dad's sudden death in the middle of third period, change my life.
name: Jared Fast

title: Owner/Creative Director
description: After almost 25 years building an ad agency from scratch into one of the most exciting creative ad shops in the Baltimore-Washington Corridor, I felt it was time to hang up my creative guns and move on to a new challenge. And after working in the business community for profit all those years I actually yearned to do something that gave back to the community and made me feel good doing so. At the time I thought going back to my roots as an educator was the best place to fulfill my dream. A sudden family death changed that and the course of my life.
name: Jared Fast

title: Director of Advertising
description: I was recruited in New York City in 1978 and invited to relocate to one of Cort's five regional headquarters, in Washington DC - home of their corporate headquarters as well. I was given the opportunity to become their first regional manager of advertising as the company experienced rapid growth. I left the company briefly in 1981 and returned in 1982 and became the company's 1st national Director of Advertising, relocating to their corporate headquarters located in Fairfax, VA. I reported to the Vice President of Marketing. As Director of Advertising, I was responsible for working with the company's five regional advertising managers to develop and implement coordinated regional and national advertising campaigns to promote Cort Furniture Rental and their Clearance Center operations. The position required me to travel extensively, all over the country opening up new showrooms. In '85 left to open my own Advertising Agency, Cort became my first client.
name: Jared Fast

Senior Health and Services Advisory in conjunction with Caring Transitions and Home Helpers

education.name: State University of New York at Stony Brook

title: Photojournalist
description: While teaching photography in a special New York State Council of the Arts public high school photography program and working towards my Masters in Education with a major in Photography, I developed a special relationship with the then Chairman of the Photography Department at the University I chose to earn my degree; The University of New York, StonyBrooke, Long Island campus. Through this wonderful relationship with the photography department Chairman I was encouraged to pursue my career as a Freelance Photojournalist. The Chairman became my professional editor and opened doors for me in Europe enabling me to pursue my dream there. After four years of teaching photography (getting married in between) I left that wonderful position and my wife rented our condominium on Long Island and relocated to London, England to begin work on getting my photographs published. I continued to shoot successfully, traveling throughout Europe documenting stories I felt were interesting and getting them published. My wife's pregnancy with our first child altered the direction of my photography career and sent us back to the United States to discover the next chapter in our lives.
name: Jared Fast

title: Business Analyst (Contract)
description:  Wrote the Support Plan and used Visio to outline the support process of the new Audio Visual/Video Conference equipments by the new Vendor using BATA’s Prince II template. This involved various workshops with the Vendor and BATA’s Services Manager and Asset \Team Lead to agree on the different support process for incident management, issue escalation and request management. This Support Plan was signed off by BATA’s IT Service Manager, Back Office Manager and the Project Manager. I was responsible for communicating the change in Vendor via emails to the business and signs in the meeting rooms were also used to communicate this change to the end users.  Requirements gathering for the legal separation of BATA and BAT Manufacturing Australia (BATMA) into two separate companies. This involved meetings with the key users from Finance, Legal and Operations to identify the information they require and to ensure that information is not shared by BATA and BATMA users. I documented the Business requirements for the legal separation, managed the UAT and liaised with the key users to warrant that the testing process is finalised prior to the 8th January 2013.  Involved in the development of the new Quality Information System. This includes identifying the gaps in the requirements by reviewing the Use Cases for the system against the feedback provided by the business users from the preview of the system, and then updating the ‘To Be’ business process. I wrote test plans for the various modules to be used in system and integration testing, and the test plans contains both the Basic flow and alternate paths. I performed system testing and used SQL to verify the integrity of the data. I also wrote the Training Manuals that details the step by step guide to using the new modules of the Quality Information System.

title: IT Business Analyst (Contract)
description:  Requirements gathering and the preparation of the Functional Specification for the Trigger Marketing program. This involved liaising with the Marketing Director and the CRM manager to finalise the project requirements and the documentation of the business workflows. The document contains the non-technical business requirements using the MoSCoW scale and Microsoft Visio was used to present the As-Is & To-Be process workflows.  Responsible for the enhancement of the online room booking system. This involves gathering requirements from the key users, working with the developers and writing the functional specifications to improve the usability and performance of the online room booking system.  Involved in the data migration of the existing CRM system into the new Page Recruiting system for India. This involves data mapping of the codes from the old system to the new system, re-defining business rules for Country specific data migration and linking business rules to the data mapping documents. The data mapping documents are grouped by the key entities of the new system.  Managing the monthly housekeeping data cleansing process for Australia/New Zealand, Asia Pacific and India. This includes running the weekly housekeeping meetings with the technical teams, liasing with the key users to gather the business requirements, working with the technical teams to convert the required business requirements into SQL scripts, testing and running the scripts.  Preparing and documentating user test plans for the existing Streamline application that integrates into the core CRM system. title: Business Analyst (Contract)
description:  Responsible for the creation of a new company in the PRMS system for Zimmer Malaysia. This involved getting approval for the initial design to the final user sign off of the new fully functional PRMS system. I wrote the functional specification and implementation plans for the new system and liaised with the key users to identify the business requirements. I analysed the existing system to determine how to customise the existing PRMS system to cater for a new system in Malaysia. The key users range from the Operations manager to Inventory Planners and Financial Accountants. I created test plans and liaised with the key users to test all parts of the system to create a fully functional PRMS system for the new office in Malaysia.  I wrote the functional specification and programs to capture the Lot id of all products for the migration of data to SAP for Australia and New Zealand. This involved analysing all the existing barcode functionalities to determine how the existing system has to be modified to capture the Lot id and uploading the data to excel for reporting. I worked closely with the Supply Chain Manager to gather the business requirements of the Lot id capture reports. These reports are used by Australia and New Zealand and are vital for the conversion of data from the Iseries into SAP. I liaised with the Supply Chain Manager on a constant basis to ensure the smooth delivery of the final reports. This allowed crucial Lot data to be made available for the migration of data to SAP for the successful conversion of PRMS to SAP in Australia and New Zealand. Key Achievements: • Created a fully functional PRMS system for the new office in Malaysia. • Provided crucial Lot data for the successful conversion of PRMS to SAP in Australia and New Zealand.

I had to confirm the business requirements in the existing functional specification and to gather additional business requirements for the creation of the conversion program that converts the old policy into the new style policy. Then the functional specification was updated accordingly with the new set of conditions for policy endorsement.  Prepare and execute Unit Test Plans for project EVO III. Liaised with programmers and testers regarding defect resolutions during System and User Acceptance Testing.  Created test files for the Travel, Home and Content products that interfaces into the Dialogue system in order to produce certificate of insurance policy to mail to the clients.  Involved in the development and testing of the new Travel insurance product (Getaway). title: Assistant Language Teacher (ALT)
description: After University I went off to Japan with the JET programme. I lived in a crap town in the middle of nowhere, populated by elderly people and coal miners. The reason for the excursion was to go and teach English in a Japanese high school. I was responsible for deciding the entire English curriculum - choosing the textbooks, creating lesson plans, writing and marking tests and leading English classes. It took a while to get used to the life as I was the only foreigner in a small town in rural Japan, but I learned to love it. During my time spent in Japan I became a master of Kyokushin Karate and stealth bukkake.
name: Thomas Evans

title: Inventor & Managing Director
description: AirDropBox is a new concept to safely enable air delivery of humanitarian aid and logistics support to areas without transport infrastructure at low cost using commonly available air transport. This is a biodegradable parachute and cardboard delivery enclosure with a crushable impact zone offering 100% sustainability whilst ensuring load integrity. AirDropBox is a concept in development and trials have confirmed that it is viable. Comprehensive patent rights have been sought and will apply worldwide with a focus on Europe, USA, Russia, China, Japan, India, the Middle East, South America, South Korea, Australia and Canada. It is a waterproofed corrugate cardboard box with built in reinforced paper parachute and integral landing crumple zone. • Fits NATO pallet and logistics standards • Range of sizes • Prepack or load on-site • Suitable for NATO range of aircraft types • Safe and easy to deploy • More accurate delivery • Precision drop for rotary wing • Safe to receive • Contents arrive in good condition • Biodegradable and environmentally friendly • Potential fuel for cooking or heating • ½ cost of current alternatives • 100% long term Sustainable product • Renewable materials used throughout • Designed to align with MOD Sustainable procurement Strategy http://airdropbox.net/
name: George Cook

title: Volunteer & Trustee
description: 4x4 Response volunteers focus on keeping Accident & Emergency going at local hospitals during extreme weather conditions by taking doctors and nurses in and out of work, carrying midwives or mothers in labour, GPs to patients, nurses and carers to the vulnerable and keeping meals on wheels going to the elderly. I sponsored a thousand high visibility rainproof winter ‘police style’ jackets for 4x4 Response volunteers across the UK in 2010 and provided a further donation for a national fuel fund. In Community Resilience UK we are also developing a Corporate 4x4 Volunteering scheme to help organisations identify staff with 4x4 vehicles, train the staff, assess the vehicles and equipment, certify for insurance to be arranged (mostly at no extra cost), enable 4x4 equipped staff to bring others in to work and arrange for 4x4 staff to be released to help their community in emergencies; we aim for 10,000 emergency trained volunteers with vehicles capable and equipped to operate in hazardous conditions. www.4x4response.info/

It also seeks to advance knowledge and understanding of how to best run and manage enterprise centres and support craft skills training for the young. title: Founder & Honorary CEO
description: During the Bosnia crisis of April 1992 to December 1995 many small charities were sending emergency supplies in small vehicles at a high cost per Kg delivered. I had the simple idea of hiring a blank 40' artic truck and having a badge from each of 20 charities in the glove box. After doing this informally for a while I eventually founded a charity called ‘Relief Aid Logistics’ on 5th December 1994, which continued my work of providing transport for small NGOs. Each set of donors and supporters could have photos of their man in Bosnia delivering their aid while wearing their badge and saving 50% of the cost of getting it there. After the Bosnia conflict I focused on the developing world and enjoyed some wonderful partnerships with charities like Faith in Action, a husband and wife team in Crawley, Sussex. Working with church groups all over the UK, Martin and Sally Jeffree send beautifully cleaned, ironed and wrapped clothes and lovingly refurbished school equipment and consumables to Africa. www.faithinaction.uk.com
name: George Cook

title: Chief Executive
description: I was 100 yards from the IRA bomb which blew up the Horse & Groom in Guildford; the bomb exploded at 20:29 on Saturday 5th October 1974, I was 18 years old. I responded without a thought, I headed in the direction of the blast and tended to the wounded. I was the first and only responder on site for what seemed like an age, although it was only a few minutes. There were 5 dead and 65 injured. This experience had a formative impact on me. Due to my work helping charities prepare for disaster, when the Civil Contingencies Bill was going through Parliament I noticed that Clause 4 included a new duty on local authorities to provide ‘advice and assistance’ to businesses but not explicitly charities. After clarifying that the voluntary sector were not included with the Attorney General’s office I discussed this with my local Member of Parliament and friend, Rt Hon Ann Widdecombe MP. We agreed to campaign together; she got the Shadow Leaders of both Houses to table amendments while I lobbied Ministers, MPs, Emergency Planning Officers and the media; the government resisted. On 15th September 2004 at the Third Reading in the upper house Lord after Lord stood up and supported our amendment, the government spokesman saw that the vote would go our way and backed down. Roger Hargreaves and Daniel Greaves, who were leading the CC Bill team at the Cabinet Office, met me in the lobby and demanded “What do you want?” I then assisted re-writing the Act, Regulations and Guidance. At 00:20 on Saturday 8th January 2005 Carlisle flooded, the council ceased to function for three days; local authorities started phoning the Charity Disaster Recovery Network (CDRN), which I ran, asking if we could help them as they were ‘non-profit’ organisations. After seeking Whitehall’s view we re-invented ourselves as Community Resilience UK, a nonprofit Community Interest Company working with government and the voluntary sector to help protect the public in emergencies. www.communityresilience.cc

title: Chief Executive
description: As Project Manager for the Microsoft project ‘Digital Pipeline’ I wanted the initiative to be clearly charitable, and so I incorporated the secretariat into a charitable company limited by guarantee called “Computers 4 Africa” on 19th August 2004. When phoning around fundraising I happened to speak to B&Q and they said I must talk to “AK”; this turned out to be Aseri Katanga, one of their 40,000 employees, who had been chosen as their ‘Hero of the Year 2006’ and was given a year off on full salary to work for charity. Aseri’s dream was to send computers to schools in his village and region in Bukoba, North West Tanzania. With B&Q’s support this then took off in its own right and has now sent 50,000 PCs for school children to use in 18 African countries. Subsequently I wanted to explore the possibility of taking the ‘Computers 4 Africa’ concept to other countries in Europe where there are few existing charity PC refurbishers. For this I established ‘Computers 4 Africa Europe’ on 19th June 2007 which is a registered charity (a ‘vzw’) in Brussels. From there it can work with the European Commission and have access to delegations from all European countries. Our third branch we hope to open soon in Switzerland. www.computers4africa.org.uk

title: Project Manager & CEO
description: In 2004 Microsoft were training teachers in Namibia and wanted to provide low cost computers. Due to my previous relationship with them and experience of refurbishing computers, I was asked to project manage this initiative which was called ‘Digital Pipeline’. The vision then expanded to providing low cost high quality refurbished computers to any who did not have access to IT, especially the developing world. In 2011 Digital Pipeline merged with another charity I formed called ‘Computers 4 Africa’. I was privileged to have Bill Gates record a personal video supporting this project. www.digitalpipeline.org

title: Founder & later Director
description: In 1998 the idea came to me of asking Chelsfield plc, the owners of 89 Albert Embankment an empty 1/4m sq ft office block next to MI6, if they would allow it to be used by charities. The answer was “Yes” and after a multi-million pound refurbishment we filled it with 40 charities, with over 1,000 staff, in 1999 including: Association of Retirement Housing, CANS Trust, Cicely Northcote Trust, Comic Relief, Elderly Accommodation Counsel, IFAW, Lady Hoare Trust, Landmine Action, Marie Curie Cancer Care, REACH, RETHINK, The Centre For Economic & Social Inclusion, The Charity Finance Directors Group, The Dystonia Society, Trinity College London Examination Board, Wildlife & Countryside Link and the World Society For The Protection of Animals. It is now known as ‘Charity Towers’. This initiative pre-dated and inspired CAN, the Ethical Property Company, Third Sector Centres and others to follow suit. In order to take forward the concept in a form that I could hand it over to someone else to run I incorporated ‘Voluntary Sector Centres’ on 19th April 2004. On 1st March 2005 the Director of Active Communities at the Home Office, Jitinder Kohli, officially opened the next charity centre at Charles House, 375 Kensington High Street with 20 Charities in 30,000 sq. ft. Charities in residence included Age Concern (Kensington and Chelsea), AMREF UK, British Suzuki Institute, Disability Equality, Faith Based Regeneration Network, Holocaust Memorial Day Trust, Image in Action, Interact Reading Service, TOPSS England, World Confederation of Physical Therapy. I retired as a Director on 15th September 2005. www.vscuk.org
name: George Cook

title: Chief Executive & later Director
description: On Saturday 15th June 1996 at 11:20 an IRA bomb hit Central Manchester. People were attempting to contact the Citizens Advice Bureaux because of the explosion, but the Bureaux couldn’t help as their offices were caught in the blast and wrecked. Shortly after I received a phone call; someone at the Citizens Advice Bureaux had heard of my work with the Charity Insurance Association and its successor the Charity Disaster Recovery Network, and thought I must know something about recovering from disasters. Within a few days I found the Citizens Advice Bureau alternative offices and helped them become fully operational again; inspired by this hundreds of charities now applied to join the Charity Disaster Recovery Network (CDRN) which I formed out of the Charity Insurance Association on 12th March 1996 to provide continuity planning for NGOs in the UK. Initially formed with 10 member charities, this network grew to 3,800 member organisations by the end of 2005 when I left. In recognition of this work I was later elected a Fellow of the Institute of Association Management. Charities whose premises suffer a disaster need replacement offices, furniture, computers and software. The CDRN sought Option Agreements from owners of empty buildings for charities to use them in an emergency. Alongside this I created Charity Logistics to meet practical needs generally, Green-Works to appeal for donations of furniture and CyberCycle to seek donations of computers, both organisations would then refurbish these donations for charity use. If charities wanted new PCs, I negotiated a charity discount arrangement with Dell who said: “Providing quality technology from Dell is the next logical step for a charity that already has office space, furniture, software, insurance, disaster recovery …” www1.euro.dell.com/content/topics/topic.aspx/emea/topics/offers/merchandising/charity_logistics_prem_page?c=uk&l=en&cs=RC1050265

title: Founding Sponsor
description: A mutual friend introduced me to Robin Hutchinson, who wore ‘dog collar’ shirts with no tie. To me this was an interesting fashion sense and led to him being nicknamed ‘The Vicar’. Over coffee we got chatting about encouraging charity work through recognition and focusing on our leaders to show the way by good example. The conversation came around to Members of Parliament and the thought arrived of putting on an event to celebrate individual MP’s charity work. So Robin said that he would organise it if I sponsored the first one; I said “yes, let’s do it” and the rest is history! Rt Hon Gordon Brown MP, then Chancellor of the Exchequer, was the winner of the Children’s Champion at the inaugural awards in 2003 and David Cameron MP the winner of the Disability Award 2004. www.charitychampionawards.com

title: Founder
description: At the time dial-up internet access was expensive. On 29th March 1999, representing the Parliamentary Information Technology Committee (PITCOM), Margaret Moran MP launched ‘Charityvfree’ in the Atrium at 4 Millbank, Westminster. This was both a free internet service for UK charities to use themselves, and for them to become virtual internet service providers to their supporters. This was delivered through our four year agreement with Internet Service Provider, Vossnet plc. Charities received a share of the local call rates, users are given 15Mb of web space and unlimited email addresses. We understood this to be the first service of its kind in the World. www.vossnet.co.uk

title: Founding Sponsor
description: I was sitting outside a café on Broadgate in the City with Richard Bowser; as the Publisher he was trying to sell me advertising space in Charity Times magazine. I tried to change the subject and starting asking what does the charity sector actually need, what might be of practical use? We started talking about charities’ special needs and who supplies charity specific products and services. So I challenged Richard to produce a ‘telephone directory’ guide with an on-line searchable database, saying that if he did I would help identify suppliers and would also sponsor it. He said he would take the idea back to Perspective Publishing and see if they were up for it. They were, it worked and is now called the Charity Times Market Guide! www.charitytimes.com/pages/ct_market_guide/categories/categoryindex.htm

title: Chief Executive & later Director
description: In October 1996 I was wondering what to do with 300 computers which had been donated by Bob Gibson of BP when they moved out of Britannic Tower; we had been given the job of clearing out the 34 storeys near Moorgate in the City of London. I wanted the PCs to go to charities, but they needed refurbishing. I heard that Bootstrap Enterprises in Hackney were closing down a computer refurbishing project informally called “CyberCycle”, as its grant money had run out. I cheekily asked if I could take on the initiative with one full-time and two part-time employees, along with volunteers, they said “Yes”. I moved CyberCycle to 89 Albert Embankment in October 1996, expanding the volunteering opportunities and eventually incorporated it on 7th May 1997. We had many IT graduates volunteer with us to gain work experience on their CVs and then succeed in getting jobs. Apparently this was noticed by Tony Blair and Peter Mandelson as they were drawing up the Labour Party Manifesto in 1996/7 and in June 1997 we were approached by the Department of Employment to be the Pathfinder for ‘New Deal’. I later shared the stage with Tony Blair at the first national New Deal Conference in 1999 and after Gordon Brown visited us, worked with him on ‘Computers Within Reach’ for the unemployed in 2000. As CyberCycle’s PCs needed software I negotiated with Microsoft a ‘Select Agreement’ to grant UK charities an 80% discount on software. This began a long-term relationship with Microsoft at several levels, eventually leading to managing their ‘Digital Pipeline’ project and the creation of ‘Computers 4 Africa’. www.computers4africa.org.uk/index.php/about-us/our-history/187-cybercycle.html
name: George Cook

title: Initiator & later Non-Executive Director
description: Wanting office furniture for charities I phoned everyone who I thought might help and ended up talking to Bob Gibson of BP in August 1996. Bob took me up to the 12th floor of Britannic Tower near Moorgate in the City of London and asked if we could clear out the whole 34 story building by 31st December 1996, which we did! We distributed an estimated 250 tonnes of office furniture to charities, including completely fitting out a 50,000 sq ft charity centre called Crown House in Sunderland with furniture and 19,000 carpet tiles and also the Big Issue’s new offices, with stock left over which we put into storage along with 300 computers for further distribution to charities. Colin Crooks, then a manager at a related project CyberCycle, was inspired by this experience to set up Green-Works on 13th June 2000, with my support as a non-executive director. Once the business became established I stepped down on 31st August 2001. Colin expanded the business rapidly opening five large warehouses across the country, giving training and employment to the unemployed. In the process Green-Works created nearly 1,000 jobs and diverted 47,000 tonnes of old furniture from landfill and put it to a socially responsible good use. www.green-works.co.uk

title: Founder
description: At 13:30 on Friday 3rd November 1995 at the QEII Centre in Westminster Rt Hon Alun Michael MP, the then Shadow Minister for the Voluntary Sector, launched the Charities Insurance Association on behalf of Relief Aid Logistics. This initiative provided charities with 20% discounted insurance premiums, through collective bulk purchasing, wider cover on specially negotiated terms for voluntary organisations, nominated loss adjusters and a free charity insurance helpline. The idea occurred to me of enabling the public to donate a small life insurance premium each month to create and bequeath a large capital sum to charity on their death. I called this ‘Legacy Enhancement’; the Express, Daily Mail and other national media published editorials on it. The Association was managed by Willis Corroon and the cover was underwritten by a panel including Commercial Union, General Accident, Royal Insurance and Sun Alliance. It soon became apparent from risk management appraisals that charities needed disaster recovery planning and practical continuity arrangements, and so this initiative developed into the Charity Disaster Recovery Network (CDRN). Realising the need charities had for disaster recovery arrangements and that they could not afford them, I formed the Charity Disaster Recovery Network (CDRN) on 12th March 1996 to provide continuity planning for NGOs in the UK. Initially there was not much take up, until June 1996 when hundreds of charities started applying because of what happened to the Citizens Advice Bureau in Manchester on the 15th June 1996. www.willis.com

title: Employee
description: After Business Studies at Guildford College and a gap year working on a ranch in Colorado USA, my first proper job was as a Salesman for Rank Xerox starting on 11th December 1978 (didn’t last long). I subsequently worked for Rentokil and others, eventually being headhunted by Mitsui & Co Ltd and to my surprise becoming a commodity trader in the City of London. Eventually I retired from employment on Friday 21st October 1988, a momentous day for me. I experimented with one or two business ideas for a few years (which didn't work) and thereafter devoted myself to charity work, starting with the Bosnia conflict in April 1992, being formalised when I created Relief Aid Logistics on 5th December 1994. www.mitsui.com

title: Student
description: I was brought up in the Middle East and Africa, it was an exciting childhood. There were several revolutions we just managed to avoid, I collected amazing pets including two chimpanzees called Charlie and Henry, drowned in a crocodile hole and was resuscitated, walked into a herd of buffalo in dense bush and survived the stampede, was the only white boy in a school of a thousand and even came out unscathed after our house was raked with gunfire. It was fun. A trouble maker at school, I was an academic failure just scraping through on little or no work. Instead I seemed to end up leading informal groups of other trouble makers, and of course getting the blame which at the time I unwisely perceived to be a badge of honour.

title: Sponsorship and Partner Manager
description: RK Motors Collector Car Auctions is a subsidiary of RK Motors Charlotte, the country’s leading builder and retailer of investment-grade classic, custom, and high performance vehicles. RK Motors Collector Car Auctions conducts live-bid vehicle auctions at which top-quality classic automobiles are offered for sale to the public. The company is expanding rapidly with plans to add new sales across the country in the coming months. RK Motors is associated with the RK Performance Center, a nationally-recognized leader in automotive restoration services; Myclassicgarage.com, a social media site for collector car enthusiasts; and, Michael Waltrip Racing, the legendary NASCAR racing team and two-time winner of the Daytona 500. I am currently looking for sponsor partners as we bring Charlotte’s largest collector car auction to the Charlotte Convention Center October 31 – November 3, 2013. Over 180,000 sq. feet of display space filled with hundreds of the finest classic and high performance cars on the market. RK Motors Collector Car Auctions will continue RK Motors’ focus on selling world-class classic and high-performance cars. The auction house will utilize many of the same resources to hand-select the cars offered for sale at their events. Dealers and private collectors from around the world are welcome to particpate. Visit www.RKMCCA.com for complete information. Or Email me at Robin.Johnson@RKMCCA.COM
name: Robin Johnson

This position was created for me as I had been involved in Sports Marketing Campaigns since 2003 working with NASCAR teams in the Nationwide Series, Truck Series and Cup Series while working as the Tour & Travel Sales Manager. The Sports Marketing programs I initiated in this position include NASCAR race team partnerships, NHRA race team partnerships, Las Vegas Motor Speedway partnership, and NFR sponsorship. I also hosted several fund raisers for charities such as the Dale Earnhardt Foundation Celebrity Poker Tournament, Kyle Busch Foundation Toy Drive, Women's Auxiliary of Motorsports Charity Auction, Speedway Children's Charities Troxel Challenge. Teresa Earnhardt also loaned me Dale Earnhardt memorabilia from Dale's famous final 76th career win to display at the property.

The auction house will utilize many of the same resources to hand-select the cars offered for sale at their events. Dealers and private collectors from around the world are welcome to particpate. Visit www.RKMCCA.com for complete information. Or Email me at Robin.Johnson@RKMCCA.COM

description: Responsible for securing partner companies to support and participate in Special Events & Promotions, Concerts, Conventions, Groups, Charity Events, New Program Development, Creative Branding, Relationship Building, Sports Marketing and other Sponsorship Campaigns to optimize brand awareness and increase traffic flow. I also book groups in the tour & travel markets. In this position I reported to the CEO and manage other special projects and solicit new opportunities to benefit the company. I worked from a remote location in a home office in Mooresville, NC as a marketing consultant with the working title VP of Sponsorship Marketing given to me by the CEO, Andy Choy. title: Corporate Director of Partnership Marketing
description: I worked for this company for almost 15 years in two postions in the Sales & Marketing Departments. As Corporate Director of Partnership Marketing, I was responsible for solicitation of Revenue Generation efforts in connection with innovative Marketing including Promotional Events like NASCAR and NHRA driver autograph sessions, Charitable Initiatives, Creative Branding, Relationship Building, and Sports Marketing to optimize brand awareness and traffic flow to the four properties. This position was created for me as I had been involved in Sports Marketing Campaigns since 2003 working with NASCAR teams in the Nationwide Series, Truck Series and Cup Series while working as the Tour & Travel Sales Manager. The Sports Marketing programs I initiated in this position include NASCAR race team partnerships, NHRA race team partnerships, Las Vegas Motor Speedway partnership, and NFR sponsorship. I also hosted several fund raisers for charities such as the Dale Earnhardt Foundation Celebrity Poker Tournament, Kyle Busch Foundation Toy Drive, Women's Auxiliary of Motorsports Charity Auction, Speedway Children's Charities Troxel Challenge. I also was involved in Public Relations efforts of opening two of the attractions on top of the Stratosphere Tower by partnering with NASCAR drivers to create a marketing buzz. The Insanity Ride in 2005 with Michael Waltrip as the "first official rider". And SkyJump in 2010 where I secured Kurt Busch to be one of the "first official jumpers" followed the next year by Carl Edwards. I also created the Dale Earnhardt display at the Stratosphere in Dec 2010 with the # 1 of 10 limited edition Dale Earnhardt Hall of Fame Camaro which was autographed by Teresa Earnhardt, Taylor Earnhardt, Kerry Earnhardt, Kelley Earnhardt Miller, Dale Earnhardt, Jr., Richard Childress and Chocolate Myers. Teresa Earnhardt also loaned me Dale Earnhardt memorabilia from Dale's famous final 76th career win to display at the property.
name: Robin Johnson

I accepted a new position as Corporate Director of Partnership Marketing that was created for me when the new ownership puchased the property in 2008. As Tour & Travel Sales Manager, I was responsible for solicitation of new business, rate negotiation and contracting of Wholesale Accounts, Group Series, Tour & Travel Groups, Wedding Groups, Sports Groups, Reunion Groups, Corporate Groups, Small Meetings, SMERF groups and other Ad Hoc Groups. I am familiar with LMS property reservations systems, SMS property reservation systems, AS 400 systems, Delphi Sales & Catering Management System as a Key Operator, BEO Set Up, Menu Set Up, Room set ups inluding Theater, Classroom, U-Shaped, Auditorium, Dinner Rounds and other common banquet set ups. I worked closely with the Catering and Convention Services to ensure all guests were happy with their events from the time the group was booked until the event was completed. Also sold group meal tickets at other property restaurants and group tickets to the thrill ride attractions to the groups. In this position I also attended trade shows and respresented the property.

Researching Bench Stock on a daily basis for parts on-hand balance and shortages.  Using FEDLOG to verify (NSN) National Stock Number and Part numbers along with the Nomenclature to insure that the proper parts are being ordered.  Communicating daily with the Battalion to determine what parts are critical for the mission to prepare the troops/ soldiers’ vehicles are mission-capable for frontline combat  If parts have a long ESD (estimated shipping date), duties include contacting the Item Manager for expedition of the part  Assigned task of briefing the Army Field Support Battalion’s Commander on all findings  Familiar with classes of supply and can advise proper handling and listing information for accountability purposes  Ordered, received, stored, maintained, and issued supplies and equipment to support daily operations  Performed inventory and financial management procedures, including ordering, receiving and storing supplies  Maintained records on incoming and outgoing stock according to Army guidelines  Responsible for material fielding plans in different geographical areas  Proficient in logistics and supply management software

title: MATERIAL COORDINATOR
description:  Quality Assurance Team: Determining the Shortage(s) or Overage(s) of the original requested quantity/correct NSN by using AMCISS (Army Material Command Installation Supply System).  Duties also include preparing Report of Discrepancy (ROD) and Material Release Orders (MRO).  Using FEDLOG to verify (NSN) National Stock Number and Part numbers along with the Nomenclature to insure that the proper parts are being ordered.  Communicating daily with vendors on dispositions and credits of damaged, non-receipt, or missing parts via email, fax, and telephone.  Updating Ships’ database by retrieving stats from Document register in MWB/Awards  Working in the Shipboard Supply Division requisitioning, receiving and dispatching parts as well as hazardous materials with updated MSDS (Material Safety Data Sheet) in form 1149.  If parts have a long ESD (estimated shipping date), duties include contacting the Item Manager for expedition of the part  Updating logistics databases for the entire APS-3 equipment AFLOAT from the document register in AWARDS/ MWB system for 8 Vessels.  Communicating with Item mangers/vendors on a daily basis regarding dispositions and credits for lost/damaged parts.  Ordered, received, stored, maintained, and issued supplies and equipment to support daily operations  Performed inventory and financial management procedures, including ordering, receiving and storing supplies
name: TARA AVILES

title: Partner, Responsabile Grafico, Docente Formatore
description: Colour Service e Cerimages srl sono società di servizi oggi legate insieme, e che operano per il settore Ceramico, dove vi sia l'esigenza della Gestione del Colore, e l'assistenza alla produzione di "ceramica digitale", ponendosi come Partner di completamento nel controllo e nella gestione del Laboratorio Ceramico. Pur essendo aziende giovani e moderne, vantano un'esperienza ultra decennale, che oggi permette di offrire i propri servizi di consulenza, formazione e vendita non solo nel settore Ceramico ma in ogni altro settore industriale dove vi sia l'esigenza della Gestione del Colore, assitenza grafica o formazione al personale. Disponendo delle più avanzate Tecnologie di Color Management la mission di Colour Service e Cerimages è quella di affiancare il cliente in un percorso di crescita che lo porti a sfruttare al meglio tutte le opportunità derivate dall'ingresso della Decorazione Digitale nel settore Ceramico, con soluzioni personalizzate adatte a soddisfare le sue esigenze.

Ma Cerimages è anche e soprattutto: Corsi base e professionali di photoshop per l’utilizzo generico e mirato allo sviluppo e gestione dei progetti ceramici Progettazione grafica per metodi ceramici tradizionali e per stampa inkjet ceramica di ultima generazione. Studio di fattibilità progettuale dell astampa inkjet. Acquisizioni spettrali, iso spettrali, rgb ad altissima definizione per ceramica inkjet e tradizionale, profilazione/modellazione dei progetti ceramici per stampa digitale e tradizionale per qualsiasi stampante o set d'inchiostri. Controllo del flusso di lavoro e della riproduttivita’. Assistenza grafica a tutti i livelli e per tutti i metodi di stampa Realizzazione di database visivi personalizzati per l’archiviazione e l’utilizzo della propria progettazione ceramica. Acquisizione digitale, assemblaggio, scomposizione colore, stampa o incisione per impianti produttivi) Fotoinserimenti e ambientazioni personalizzate (anche con location esclusive)

title: SENIOR LOGISTICS ANALYST II
description:  Assist with training of the new hire regarding various task such as email traffic research, use of the LMP module process, CRSP receiving, AWRDS pulls, MRO process, plant to plant movements, plan to plan movements, and processing 1348s, etc.  Creating queries using (SQL) Structured Query Language on a daily basis for research on serial no, niin, elid, location, etc. for purposes of providing information as a resource center in regards of research, troubleshooting, and resolving data discrepancies within AWRDS while providing data integrity.  Maintain data integrity, while simultaneously ensuring multi-functional procedures at a high level of customer service to our client  Create queries to establish shipment and updates of equipment in AWRDS with correct quantities, condition codes, document numbers, serial numbers, etc.  Process data into the LMP module: integrates with LMP to maintain accountability and asset visibility through AWRDS and LMP databases.  Perform all AWRDS data entry in relation to inventory updates to include CRSP receiving equipment from plan to plan  Request disposition instructions on Military equipment  Create MROs (Material Release Order) and process records of wholesale assets in AWRDS based on 1348’s on receipt of incoming records  Update records in AWRDS based on documents received ( 1348s and IARs)  Provide data reports to ITT work centers upon request  Use AWRDS query module to obtain information and resolve problems  MRPAT (Mobile Retrograde Property Assessment Team).: Processing wholesale equipment, received by the WRO (Wholesale Responsible Officer), into AWRDS and LMP Distribution in order to relieve the Turn-in Unit of accountability of retail stock equipment.  Operates accounting and visibility programs such as LMP, AWRDS, and the TPE Planner (LIW/TRAM) at the MRPAT locations  Supports the RESET/Retrograde mission throughout Kuwait.
name: TARA AVILES

description:  Maintained and supervised accountability of assigned equipment  Researched discrepancies through physical inventories and prepared proper documentations to resolve discrepancies  Supervised administrative and supply transactions during the absence of immediate supervisor  Maintained supporting documents and established tracking systems for equipment turned in for maintenance  Managed the property accountability of four subordinate organizations utilizing Army supply measures regarding hand receipts, shortage annexes and scheduled inventories.  Advising the Supply Manager and Maintenance Manager of necessary follow-ups (AF1) and Cancellations (AC1) through AWARDS system needed (AWARDS certified). Researching Bench Stock on a daily basis for parts on-hand balance and shortages.  Using FEDLOG to verify (NSN) National Stock Number and Part numbers along with the Nomenclature to insure that the proper parts are being ordered.  Communicating daily with the Battalion to determine what parts are critical for the mission to prepare the troops/ soldiers’ vehicles are mission-capable for frontline combat  If parts have a long ESD (estimated shipping date), duties include contacting the Item Manager for expedition of the part  Assigned task of briefing the Army Field Support Battalion’s Commander on all findings  Familiar with classes of supply and can advise proper handling and listing information for accountability purposes  Ordered, received, stored, maintained, and issued supplies and equipment to support daily operations  Performed inventory and financial management procedures, including ordering, receiving and storing supplies  Maintained records on incoming and outgoing stock according to Army guidelines  Responsible for material fielding plans in different geographical areas  Proficient in logistics and supply management software
address: 555 South Flower Street Suite 3700 Los Angeles, California 90071-2300 United States
name: TARA AVILES

groups.name: CSCMP - Council of Supply Chain Management Professionals

title: MATERIAL COORDINATOR
description:  Quality Assurance Team: Determining the Shortage(s) or Overage(s) of the original requested quantity/correct NSN by using AMCISS (Army Material Command Installation Supply System).  Duties also include preparing Report of Discrepancy (ROD) and Material Release Orders (MRO).  Using FEDLOG to verify (NSN) National Stock Number and Part numbers along with the Nomenclature to insure that the proper parts are being ordered.  Communicating daily with vendors on dispositions and credits of damaged, non-receipt, or missing parts via email, fax, and telephone.  Updating Ships’ database by retrieving stats from Document register in MWB/Awards  Working in the Shipboard Supply Division requisitioning, receiving and dispatching parts as well as hazardous materials with updated MSDS (Material Safety Data Sheet) in form 1149.  If parts have a long ESD (estimated shipping date), duties include contacting the Item Manager for expedition of the part  Updating logistics databases for the entire APS-3 equipment AFLOAT from the document register in AWARDS/ MWB system for 8 Vessels.  Communicating with Item mangers/vendors on a daily basis regarding dispositions and credits for lost/damaged parts.  Ordered, received, stored, maintained, and issued supplies and equipment to support daily operations  Performed inventory and financial management procedures, including ordering, receiving and storing supplies
name: TARA AVILES

groups.name: CSCMP - Council of Supply Chain Management Professionals

title: SUPPLY TECH
description: Duties include preparing the ROD (Report of Discrepancy). Communicate with vendors on dispositions and credits of damaged, non-receipt, or missing parts on a daily basis via email, fax, and telephone. Working in the Supply Division requisitioning parts to include hazardous materials with updated MSDS (Material safety data sheet) on form 1149. Updating databases of parts ordered for several ships overseas. Communicating with Item mangers/vendors on a daily basis regarding dispositions and credits for lost/damaged parts. Scan form 1381 to produce a material release order (MRO) out of Maintenance Workbench (MWB.Awards) and sent to the appropriate shop/department. Ordered, received, stored, maintained, and issued supplies and equipment to support daily operations Performed inventory and financial management procedures, including ordering, receiving and storing supplies
name: TARA AVILES
